item.title: Christopher Wool’s Punk-Rock Art Show in a Fidi Tower
item.description: The blue-chip artist is over museums, galleries — and pretty much everything else.

item.title: Tierra Whack Takes Her Mask Off
item.description: Known for her clever lyrics and eccentric music videos, the rapper gets surprisingly vulnerable on her debut album.

item.title: The Mr. Rogers of Columbus, Ohio
item.description: The poet Hanif Abdurraqib is as idiosyncratic as his unclassifiable new book.

item.title: Picking His Fights
item.description: The twists and turns of Jake Gyllenhaal’s unlikely, unsettling action career have brought him toRoad House.

item.title: The Troubadour
item.description: How Alynda Segarra, a former train-hopping punk from the Bronx, became one of America’s best songwriters.

item.title: WithChallengers,Justin Kuritzkes Serves an Ace
item.description: His first movie script for the sexy tennis drama has taken him from struggling playwright to in-demand screenwriter.

item.title: Emil Ferris Still Believes in Monsters
item.description: The graphic novelist’s debut,My Favorite Thing Is Monsters, was a hit. Seven years later—after a contentious lawsuit—the sequel is finally coming.

item.title: Ella Purnell Is Hollywood’s New Favorite Action Hero
item.description: Yellowjacketsfans craved more of her. Tim Burton couldn’t resist her peculiar eyes. Now, the actress has everyone falling for her inFallout.

item.title: Is This Your King?
item.description: House of the Dragon’s Tom Glynn-Carney is so good at playing pathetic you almost forget you’re supposed to hate him.

item.title: Annie Baker Goes to Hollywood
item.description: The renowned playwright switches mediums with her sneakily expansive debut film,Janet Planet, about a possessive mother-daughter relationship.

item.title: From the Archives: Eddie Murphy Live
item.description: The razor-edged king of late-night comedy, profiled in 1982.

item.title: Lev Grossman Takes His Time
item.description: The author ofThe Magiciansreturns to adult fiction withThe Bright Sword.It only took ten years and a transpacific move.

item.title: Lionel Boyce IsThe Bear’s Secret Sauce
item.description: As Marcus,Boyce is the guy everyone wants to be around. He’s having that effect on Hollywood too.

item.title: Put Maya Erskine in Everything
item.description: PEN15introduced her as a gonzo comedic talent.Mr. & Mrs. Smithmakes a convincing case for her as a rom-com lead.

item.title: Saoirse-Monica Jackson GoesDerryFree
item.description: After playing a teenager in Northern Ireland, Saoirse-Monica Jackson is hell-bent on doing something different.

item.title: Casey McQuiston Is Trojan-Horsing Trans Romance
item.description: “You’re gonna be 60 percent of the way in before you know that’s what you’re reading.”

item.title: Therapy Daddy
item.description: Phil Stutz has made a career in Hollywood doing what most psychologists advise against: telling his patients exactly what to do.

item.title: Moses Sumney’s Time Machine
item.description: This summer, he’s got music for ’90s R&B lovers and the movieMaXXXinefor ’80s horror freaks.

item.title: Naomi Ackie Knows She’s Good. When Will the Box Office?
item.description: The actor has critical acclaim but no mainstream success. She hopes Zoë Kravitz’s thrillerBlinkTwicechanges that.

item.title: Eric Goode’s Monkey Business
item.description: How a former nightclub impresario and reptile enthusiast became one of the most successful documentary filmmakers of our time.

item.title: Garth Greenwell’s Grand Romance
item.description: The author explores the tender side of long-term partnership amid a health crisis in his best novel yet.

item.title: Kaytranada Owns His Influence
item.description: Once modern dance music’s best-kept secret, the Canadian DJ-producer is ready to go bigger.

item.title: Anna Sawai: ‘I Have This Weird Confidence’
item.description: She is now the first Japanese actress to win an Emmy for her lead performance inShōgun.

item.title: Hot Commodity
item.description: In Sally Rooney’s novels, love is always being bought, sold, or reduced to tropes. But this is also what makes it real.

item.title: Jamie xx Didn’t Ruin Club Music
item.description: But that hasn’t stopped the producer from worrying about his impact.

item.title: How Erin Foster’s Jewish Conversion Led to Netflix’sNobody Wants This
item.description: She spent the past decade turning her Hollywood life into so-so content. Her new rom-com series, with Kristen Bell and Adam Brody, might be different.

item.title: Anora’s ‘Russian Timothée Chalamet’ Is Just Happy to Be Here
item.description: “I’m just some weird guy who somehow became a part of Sean Baker’s movie,” says actor Mark Eydelshteyn.

item.title: No Longer Just a Nepo Friend
item.description: After years in celebrity orbit, Owen Thiele is taking center stage.

item.title: Nicole Scherzinger Never Stopped Dreaming
item.description: The former Pussycat Doll stages a comeback withSunset Blvd.on Broadway.

item.title: Kehinde Wiley Can’t Believe This Is Happening to Him
item.description: He built an empire out of painting young Black men into art history. Can it survive accusations of sexual assault?

item.title: ‘I’m Not Letting You Laugh at Me. I’m Perfect.’
item.description: Twenty years into his stand-up career, Anthony Jeselnik remains the king of crossed lines.

item.title: Moonlight in the Lion’s Den
item.description: Why Barry Jenkins gave up his improvisational shooting style to spend four years makingMufasaon a soundstage.

item.title: Big Tits, Trim Ankles, and a Peabody
item.description: Bridget Everett reflects on the life and death of her TV masterpieceSomebody Somewhere:“I can’t imagine anything else being this good.”

item.title: Lorraine O’Grady Finally Has the World’s Attention
item.description: At 86, the artist had cemented her (belated) trailblazing status.

item.title: The Voice Whisperer
item.description: Eric Vetro teaches the stars how to sing for their Oscars. “They don’t have a vocal-coach award, but if there was one, he’d be Meryl Streep.”

item.title: Sarah McNally’s Book Club
item.description: The owner of the McNally Jackson literary empire is reshaping the city’s reading life.

item.title: Trust the Kieran Culkin Process
item.description: First, he nearly dropped out ofA Real Pain. Then he convinced Jesse Eisenberg to change the way he directs.

item.title: Adrien Brody Found the Part
item.description: The Brutalistis his best, most personal work sinceThe Pianist.

item.title: The Resilient Natasha Rothwell
item.description: The writer and actor returns toThe White Lotusjust as the show she created,How to Die Alone,has been canceled.

item.title: Will Shortz Is Back in the Game
item.description: TheTimes’ crossword-puzzle editor returns to work — and table tennis — after two strokes that nearly ended his career.

item.title: Cynthia Ozick Is Undiminished
item.description: Nearing 97, she’s universally praised, freshly republished, and (maybe even) more widely read than ever. She’s also a world-class emailer.

item.title: Whitney Cummings Finds Her People
item.description: The comedian’s politics has changed. So has her audience.

item.title: ‘A Black Woman Got Them Judy Blume’
item.description: Mara Brock Akil reimagines a controversial tale of teen sexual awakening in the sumptuous new Netflix seriesForever.

item.title: The Many Lives of Whitney Leavitt
item.description: MomTok might not survive the reality-TV spotlight, but its breakout star has a backup plan (or several).

item.title: Since Dorian Died
item.description: Two years after the death of his son, Ben Kweller doesn’t want to waste any more time.

item.title: Michael B. Jordan Did the Impossible
item.description: In an era of mounting crises in Hollywood, theSinnersstar got people off their couches and into theaters for an original film.

item.title: ‘The Depth Is in the Pictures, Not What I Say About Them’
item.description: Rosalind Fox Solomon made haunting photographs for 50 years. She told us about her trajectory from Tennessee housewife to artist.

item.title: If the Scrubs Fit
item.description: OnER, Noah Wyle was a prime-time TV star. In the streaming era, he’s just happy to be part of the company.

item.title: It Broke Her, Too
item.description: What Kaitlyn Dever does inThe Last of Usis devastating. It’s nothing compared to what was happening behind the scenes.

item.title: Jennifer Love Hewitt Wasn’t Sure She Wanted to Come Back
item.description: The sexism the actress faced early in her career almost kept her from returning to the franchise that made her famous.
